results.title: The Killing times
results.brief_description: In August 1928, in the desert of Central Australia, seven white Australians murdered seventeen members of the Walbiri tribe. The Coniston Massacre, as it became known, was the last large-scale massacre of Aborigines in Australia. This video dramatises the massacre and the subsequent Federal Inquiry, as well as the eventual victory of the Walbiri for the right to return and live where they were born. The cast includes Ray Barrett, Max Gillies and Martin Vaughan. Narrated by Bob Plasto. Teacher’s notes accompany the video.

results.title: Mimi pulka
results.creator_credit: Catherine Adams, Ruth Carr, SBS-TV and Voice Productions
results.brief_description: In an effort to break down existing myths about HIV/AIDS and present the information in a way that was culturally appropriate for Aborigines, the Kimberley Aboriginal Medical Service in Broome commissioned a play entitled “No prejudice” and sent it on tour throughout the Kimberley region. This video follows the touring company of five actors and advisers and highlights the importance of why alternatives to the written word are necessary to a people whose culture is essentially oral.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Catherine Adams, Ruth Carr, SBS-TV and Voice Productions

results.title: Black man's houses
results.creator_credit: Steve Thomas, John Moore, Australian Film Commission and Open Channel Productions
results.brief_description: More than a hundred years after the First Nations peoples of Tasmania were declared “extinct” by white historians, local descendants set out to reclaim the lost graves of their ancestors on Flinders Island in Bass Strait. The neglected burial site at Wybalenna was, in the 1830’s, Australia’s first segregated Reserve, under the directorship of George Augustus Robinson and is now a battleground that divides a community. The film explores the survival and recognition of cultural identities, in the context of a colonialist settler society. Winner Best Australian Film at the Melbourne Film Festival.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Steve Thomas, John Moore, Australian Film Commission and Open Channel Productions

results.title: Still on the same way
results.creator_credit: Graham Cavanagh, Australia. Special Broadcasting Service and Orcalia Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
With the help of the First Nations people from Gilwi Community (near Timber Creek, Northern Territory), Bob Ellis of the Sacred Sites Authority and spokesmen from the Northern Land Council, this program explores what sacred sites are, some First Nations concepts of land tenure and how development by white Australia is managed in the Northern Territory through a mandatory consultation process, set down in the Aboriginal Land Rights Act.

results.title: The Broken covenant
results.creator_credit: David M. Thompson, ABC-TV (Australia) and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Encounters”.
Many of Australia’s urban First Nations people live in appalling physical conditions and are seen by some Australians as outcasts. But to Father Ted Kennedy, a Catholic priest who works in the inner-city suburb of Redfern, many of these marginalised people retain an essential quality of life missing in white society.
results.description:

results.title: Familiar places
results.creator_credit: David MacDougall and Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies
results.brief_description: Anthropologist Peter Sutton is taken by an Aboriginal family, the Naponans, to map hereditary clan country in northern Queensland where they hope to live one day. To the children it is all new; to an old man it brings back vivid memories. [Source: https://aiatsis.gov.au/publication/35836 Last accessed 12/7/2023]
results.creator_credit_for_label: David MacDougall and Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies
results.description: Anthropologist Peter Sutton is taken by an Aboriginal family, the Naponans, to map hereditary clan country in northern Queensland where they hope to live one day. results.title: Takeover
results.creator_credit: Judith MacDougall, David MacDougall and Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies
results.brief_description: On 13th March, 1978 the Queensland government announced its intention to take over the management of the Aurukun Aboriginal Reserve from the Uniting Church. The people of Aurukun complained bitterly, believing that the Church was more sympathetic to their aims and fearing that the State was merely seeking easier access to the rich bauxite deposits on their Reserve. When the Federal Government took the side of the Aurukun people the stage was set for national confrontation. Shows the situation at Aurukun during those crucial three weeks.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Judith MacDougall, David MacDougall and Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies
results.description: On 13th March, 1978 the Queensland government announced its intention to take over the management of the Aurukun Aboriginal Reserve from the Uniting Church. The people of Aurukun complained bitterly, believing that the Church was more sympathetic to their aims and fearing that the State was merely seeking easier access to the rich bauxite deposits on their Reserve. When the Federal Government took the side of the Aurukun people the stage was set for national confrontation. Shows the situation at Aurukun during those crucial three weeks.

results.title: Sons of Namatjira
results.creator_credit: Curtis Levy and Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies
results.brief_description: Keith Namatjira and his relatives paint in the style of his famous father, Albert and live in an artist’s camp on the outskirts of Alice Springs. The film highlights problems which the Namatjiras confront in their relationship with the world outside their community.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Curtis Levy and Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies
